You may not give your gut much thought beyond how much your stomach might be rumbling or whether your [waistline](https://www.muscleandfitness.com/muscle-fitness-hers/hers-workouts/7-exercises-sculpt-hourglass-figure/) looks a little bloated over your [skinny jeans](https://www.muscleandfitness.com/muscle-fitness-hers/hers-features/6-sexy-denim-jeans-athletes/). But your [gut is much more](https://www.muscleandfitness.com/muscle-fitness-hers/hers-features/three-steps-healthier-gut/) than a depository for your last meal—it's home to [microbes](https://www.muscleandfitness.com/muscle-fitness-hers/hers-supplements/how-prebiotics-and-probiotics-keep-your-gut-healthy/) and bacteria that play a crucial role in everything from absorbing nutrients and boosting immunity to reducing inflammation and even balancing your mood. "Your gut, and the microbiome it contains, is extremely important to your overall health," explains [Raphael Kellman](https://www.yelp.com/biz/kellman-center-new-york-6), M.D., founder of the [Kellman Center for Integrative and Functional Medicine](https://kellmancenter.com/) in New York and author of [The Microbiome Diet](https://www.amazon.com/Microbiome-Diet-Scientifically-Restore-Permanent-ebook/dp/B00J1JPTNY). The microbiome is a miniature world inside your gastrointestinal tract that makes up 90% of the cells in your body.
